11:06 am
BE11:07am

Which isn't really that clear. Here's Jim Reid at Deutsche.

BE11:07am

There appeared to be a few reasons for justifying the price action. The ‘stealth
taper’ of sorts by the BoJ certainly seemed to get the most airtime though after the BoJ cut long-end bond purchases. While it seemed to come as a surprise, it’s worth noting that the absolute purchase level was still within the BoJ target range of purchases, and with the BoJ also focused on controlling the yield curve the bigger test is perhaps the BoJ’s tolerance to let 10y JGBs move north of the 10bp ceiling should Treasuries sustainably move higher. For what it’s worth JGBs are up 1.3bp this morning but seem relatively calm while the Yen has strengthened c0.3%.

red added 5bps within minutes after an hour ago. just one thing after another for bonds this wk.
AAAA bonjour les amis !
Tom Dalgleish I wish FT gave me subscription option of 10 articles a week instead of the full package
GBKrona ARe growing yields the reason for jump in life insurers today (PRU, Aviva, Legal & General); or is it due to potential M&A interest?
BE11:08am

Also weighing on rates yesterday was primary issuance with a fairly decent
pickup in sovereign and corporate issuance expected this week. Around $60bn of combined issuance is expected from sovereign deals from the US, Japan,
Germany and the UK this week according to Bloomberg while €20bn of European corporate issuance is expected and US domestic IG issuance is also active with $14.7bn in total pricing.
Remember that in our outlook we showed that 2018 will likely be the first year in seven where QE doesn’t increase relative to net supply of government bonds (see figure 18 and page 16 of this doc). We think we’re at a turning point for the technicals in government bonds around now and perhaps as the technicals turns, sell-off can occur more easily than when we were at peak QE and peak technicals. Yesterday’s BoJ news was pretty minor so imagine the scenario if
something major happened! However it will probably still take inflation beats to
really turbo charge any bond sell off. We think there’s a decent chance we get closer to this after Q2 this year but before that Friday’s US CPI is an obvious focal point in which to test the bond market.

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Yeah, Albert's also pinning stuff on Japan

BE11:08am

(Sorry, don't have the charts referred to above.)

PM11:08am

The ECB has followed the Fed in tapering its massive QE programme, while in Japan the monetary floodgates still remain fully open – but for how much longer? Many clients we meet are fully invested bears, nervously looking over their shoulder for signals of the next ‘Great Unwind’. Most western commentators do not give developments in Japan as much attention as it deserves. Could it be that a surprise monetary tightening in Japan will finally burst the global asset price bubble?

11:08 am
PM11:09am

Much of the template for our Ice Age thesis came from my observations of equity and bond market behaviour during Japan’s lost decade through the 1990s. I was then penning the Global Strategy Weekly at Kleinwort Benson from 1988 and the advantage of doing exactly the same job for 30 years is that you get to recognise patterns of market and economic behaviour. However, even that is not enough to make you a good market timer. I have called the top of this equity rally several times and I have been wrong time and time again, so I am not going to waste your time calling another top – for this week at least! The FT’s chief leader writer, Robert Armstrong, participating in a round table outlook for 2018, described me as having “correctly predicted 10 of the last one market crash”. Ouch! But some leading strategists who cannot conceivably be described as perma- or uber-bears are getting very worried. Our own Head of Asset Allocation, Alain Bokobza has, against the trend, just crossed over to the dark side, slashing his equity exposure

PM11:09am

Many investors we speak to are fully invested bears who expect further upside as they see nothing to de-rail the current rally. In the US, bullishness among both retail and professional advisors is at extreme highs –link. But even bullish investors should look over their shoulder to see what could derail this nirvana. We have written about likely triggers before, but it might not be one of the usual suspects, like higher Fed rates, that collapses this bubble. A big hat tip to the excellent Kevin Muir at The Macro Tourist who got me thinking about Japan. Could things be going so well in Japan that an unexpected tightening causes the yen to surge at a time when almost all investors, including myself, expect never-ending yen weakness. Could Japan now provide the trigger for a major market disruption?

Golly Galoshes Perma Bears. When I grow up, I'm going to spend my entire career being wrong until the one day I'm right, then I'm going to spend the rest of my career being wrong again but talking about the one day I was right.

The group has delivered 5% volume growth in 2017 and, combined with ASP increases and a better margin performance, PBT should be in line with market expectations. The forward order book is slightly behind the prior year. However, this is partly due to the timing of site openings and management remains confident of volume growth in FY18. No change to forecasts at this stage or to capital returns. After a strong performance in 2017 (+34%) and now trading in line with our target price, we pull our recommendation back to Hold from Add.

Golly Galoshes I must admit to not counting either of those two authors in the permabear camp but a Mr Elder of this parish mentioned an 'Albert' - and I don't think he meant Victoria's husband
BE11:16am

While the forward order book is down by c3% to £1.63bn, this is due
partly to the timing of site openings and a lower number of affordable units.
There was no change to guidance in the November update, when management
pointed to 7-8% volume growth over 2017-18. Having delivered c5% in 2017,
this implies c2-3% for FY18 (in line with our forecasts). Build cost inflation for
FY18 is expected to be similar to FY17 (c3-4%).

BE11:21am

Today adds some useful detail to that call, to help emphasise the point.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian If everyone has an ICO then you have oversupply of something that has no value. You should know where that will end. Don't confuse interesting technology and useful technology with having any inflationary value. To be a useful currency it first has to be proven to be stable.
PM11:21am

Liberum has a comprehensive summary of the details

PM11:21am

Most providers and distributors were unable to offer a satisfactory definition of the target market, relying on broad investor descriptions e.g. "experienced", "sophisticated" and "financially literate." The letter went on to state that, "In our view, excessively broad definitions of target markets may lead firms to conclude that CFD's are suitable and/or appropriate for the majority of potential customers, even when this is unlikely to be the case.";
76% of retail customers lost money in the 12 month period under review (July'15-June'16)
Flawed due diligence processes for taking on new distributors
Several distributor firms had problems with their processes and criteria when categorizing clients as elective professionals. To quote the letter, "This raises concerns of potential non-compliance with this rule. We expect firms to go beyond asking clients for their own opinion of their knowledge and experience, as this is inevitably subjective and is unlikely to be reliable, at least on its own. Firms should request facts and information to support their assessment of a prospective client's expertise, knowledge and experience."
Suggestion that providers and distributors may be failing to conduct their activities in accordance with the FCA's "Principles for Businesses, the Clients best interest rule and Senior management arrangement arrangements, systems and controls (SYSC).
The letter states that, "In our view, none of the 19 providers in our review were acting in line with our guidance (RPPD) - (The Responsibilities of Providers and Distributors for the Fair Treatment of Customers), with specific regard to information shared with distributors to ensure product suitability for end clients. Additionally, these firms could not demonstrate that they were acting with due skill, care and diligence."

Tom Dalgleish @Fletch, where ICO's are only backed by their supposed scarcity
You can call me Al @TomD Last year the traffic cops in Zim were happy to accept bottles of ice cold water from the boot in lieu of a dollar for imagined road traffic offences. So anything can be a currency. That's not an endorsement of Pennon etc with Ofwat coming over the horizon...

Yep -- as in, CFD brokers having absolutely no idea who they're selling to.

And a lot on the distribution networks, which seem to have been put together on a due diligence procedure I can summarise as: "will you sell this? Okay, sell this."

Pernaffo @Tom Dalgleish, agree and disagree. in my mind the "app" developed are key. Then the token is just something that is and must be inherently existent in that environment. and I agree with @FATDAZ that this link must be clear. I tend to associate ICOs to basically "games", where you have some sort of monopoly money traded. Now, if we all start playing monopoly, and the only way to play is to own monopoly money (which is the exclusive currency used in Monopoly), then I guess monopoly money gets some value... there is no government replacement in monopoly, it's just a game, it's just an app...

BE11:31am

Here's Barclays on IG, which has been arguing for a time that regulatory tightening will be a small negative for the size operators and possibly even a positive as it shakes out the marginal types.

BE11:31am

Overall, we accept that there are still lingering risks for the IG investment case given the focus on the industry from regulators. However, our view is that IG Group is positioned at the premium end of the industry, as evidenced by the fact that 9% of clients generate c80% of IG’s revenue (source: IG Group FY17 results).

· We do not believe that these investors, many of whom the company anticipates will become ‘elective professionals’, are the area concern for the regulator.

· We believe the focus from regulators, not unreasonably, is on protecting customers who may not fully understand the risks of a leveraged financial product such as a CFD. IG appears to share this view, as evidenced by the front page comment in its FY17 results, part of which we quote here: “At IG we are proud of our track record of compliance and our culture of placing the client at the heart of our business. We try to do what is right, not just what is possible under the rules. We understand that leveraged trading products aren't right for everyone, and we therefore believe that it is in the best interests of many consumers to be prevented from accessing them. We seek to only offer our products to an appropriate audience and consistently innovate to improve client outcomes.”

Pseudonym @Pernaffo Any such token can be immediately rendered worthless by the app owner closing the app. Such risk really renders the token worthless except as a short term medium of exchange where no-one holds it.
11:31 am
BE11:31am

Same argument re CMC, via Peel Hunt.

BE11:32am

This year regulatory clarity and the impact on profitability of leveraged trading providers is likely to be made clear. The FCA wants to ensure there is a clear distinction between retail and professional and that retail clients are targeted with FCA deemed suitable products, whilst ensuring full disclosure.
Following the introduction of MiFID II and a brief public consultation (expected to complete in January) relating to the December ESMA statement, we expect
that new rules (relating to retail clients) will be set. CMC is focused on higher
value clients (where the impact should be limited as the majority can elect to be ‘professional’), which generate c75% of CMC revenue. Our CMC forecasts are already discounting the regulatory impact and appear conservative given that we are assuming a 13% fall in European revenue, whereas IG announced that
proposed regulatory change would have impacted its previous year of revenue by less than 10%. Furthermore, the long-term impact from regulation is that the tail of smaller players diminishes, reducing competition and improving prospects for the established players. CMC is trading on an EV/EBITDA (annualised to December 2018) of c8x, which in our view inherently discounts a pessimistic
outcome from these regulations, and fails to recognise the strength of the platform and improved market position. We therefore retain our Buy recommendation and target price of 210p.

wayneJ @Fatdaz - it was 'too hot to handle'......(I will collect my coat)
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian If you think about it the CFD market is really a threat to the secondary and hence primary markets of the LSE etc.. because no real underlying assets need to be bought/sold.
Mr Diamond LoL - IG went after clients that they helped blow up in the SNB shake out a few years ago.. now holding themselves out with high morals
red tthats all fine but the problem is its hard to make a living from spreads off folks that know what they are doing (require 100% hedging). the money is made from those who have no clue. and here is the fault in the business model.
BE11:33am

BE11:33am

Our recently revised forecasts for Plus500 (BUY, TP 1231p) already carry an assumption for reduced leverage i.e. our ARPU forecast for FY18 is $1,277, falling to $1,239 in FY19, reductions of c.40% on FY16.

Our forecasts, recommendation and TP on IG Group are currently Under Review but we do caution that the company's guidance of a, "less than 10%" hit to revenue from reduced leverage could prove to be an optimistic assumption.

Plus500 trades on a CY18 PE of 9.2x, falling to 9.0x and yields 6.5% rising to 6.7%, whereas IG Group trades on a consensus FY18 (May YE) PE of 15.6x, rising to 16.5x and yields 4.4% rising to 4.5%,

Frontier expects to report sales of c.£19m in 1H18 – modestly ahead of the comparative period (£18.1m), thanks to the continued performance of both games, particularly Elite Dangerous, which launched on PlayStation 4 in June 2017. Sales also responded well in price promotion events – offered at Thanksgiving and Christmas (the latter being post period-end). As per guidance, we leave our full-year sales estimate unchanged, implying 2H18E sales of £10.7m. This compares with £19.3m achieved in 2H17, where trading benefitted from Planet Coaster’s November 2016 launch. Notwithstanding the absence of a similar event in 2H18E, we believe risk to FY18E is to the upside.

irst half revenues demonstrate the continued strong performance of the first two launched franchises through game development, community support and a successful monetisation strategy as well as the sales uptick from launching across more platforms.
